Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: 12. Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain its premises in a safe condition, failing to warn of the dangerous condition, and failing to take prompt corrective action in violation of Massachusetts negligence law.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely concerns a plaintiff’s negligence claim against a supermarket for failing to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition and to take steps to prevent or correct a dangerous condition (a grape on the floor). The court reaffirms that Massachusetts premises liability law requires store owners to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises safe and discusses liability where an owner fails to take reasonable precautions against foreseeable hazards arising from its mode of operation. Although framed in terms of notice and mode of operation, the decision directly reflects the duty to maintain safe premises and to prevent or correct dangerous conditions under Massachusetts negligence law.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property "in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk." … [U]nder the mode of operation approach, … a store owner will be liable to a plaintiff injured as a result of a dangerous condition … only if the owner could reasonably foresee that the dangerous condition could occur … and the owner took inadequate steps to forestall resulting injuries.

Davis v. Stop & Shop Supermarkets Co., 3.raw_text: Davis v. Stop & Shop Supermarkets Co., 312 Mass. 557 (1942)
Davis v. Stop & Shop Supermarkets Co., 3.proposition: 12. Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain its premises in a safe condition, failing to warn of the dangerous condition, and failing to take prompt corrective action in violation of Massachusetts negligence law.
Davis v. Stop & Shop Supermarkets Co., 3.support_reasoning: The case is a criminal appeal concerning assault and battery with a dangerous weapon and the law of attempt in the context of a suicide attempt. It does not involve premises liability, duty to maintain safe conditions, warn of dangers, or take corrective action under Massachusetts negligence law. Therefore, it does not support the stated negligence proposition.
Davis v. Stop & Shop Supermarkets Co., 3.relevant_excerpt: The judge instructed the jury that if they believed that she was engaged in an attempt to commit suicide and that Morse was injured in endeavoring to prevent her from doing so, then the defendant was guilty of an assault and battery upon him with a dangerous weapon... She was engaged in the accomplishment of an unlawful purpose, and she had gone so far in realizing her object that it was reasonably probable that she would have succeeded if her efforts had not been frustrated by the intervention of Morse.

Sullivan v. Stop & Shop Supermarkets Co..raw_text: Sullivan v. Stop & Shop Supermarkets Co., 261 Mass. 196 (1970)
Sullivan v. Stop & Shop Supermarkets Co..proposition: 12. Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain its premises in a safe condition, failing to warn of the dangerous condition, and failing to take prompt corrective action in violation of Massachusetts negligence law.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: 12. Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain its premises in a safe condition, failing to warn of the dangerous condition, and failing to take prompt corrective action in violation of Massachusetts negligence law.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurring opinion discussing the abandonment of common-law invitee/licensee distinctions and briefly questioning the treatment of trespassers. It does not articulate the elements of negligence or specifically address an occupier’s duty to maintain premises safely, warn of dangers, or take corrective action under Massachusetts law. Without the main opinion text, this snippet alone does not clearly support the specific negligence proposition stated.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

D'Annolfo v. Stoneham Housing Auth., 375.raw_text: D'Annolfo v. Stoneham Housing Auth., 375 Mass. 650 (1978)
D'Annolfo v. Stoneham Housing Auth., 375.proposition: 12. Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain its premises in a safe condition, failing to warn of the dangerous condition, and failing to take prompt corrective action in violation of Massachusetts negligence law.
D'Annolfo v. Stoneham Housing Auth., 375.support_reasoning: The opinion is an eminent domain/valuation case about fair market value, zoning probabilities, special verdicts, JNOV, and remittitur. It does not involve premises liability, negligence, duties to maintain property safely, or duties to warn or correct dangerous conditions. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the Massachusetts negligence principles described in the proposition.
D'Annolfo v. Stoneham Housing Auth., 375.relevant_excerpt: We have recognized that a trial judge has a range of discretion in land damage cases in admitting evidence of value based on a use of the land which requires a zoning change or other preliminary municipal authorization. An opinion of value founded on such a use has been held properly admissible where, “upon all the evidence in the case, the jury could warrantably find that a willing buyer’s evaluation of the land could be influenced by the possibility of a change in zoning.”

Monteiro v. Stop & Shop, 871 N.E.2d 859.proposition: 12. Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain its premises in a safe condition, failing to warn of the dangerous condition, and failing to take prompt corrective action in violation of Massachusetts negligence law.
Monteiro v. Stop & Shop, 871 N.E.2d 859.support_reasoning: The case is an Illinois premises-liability slip-and-fall decision applying Illinois negligence and premises-liability principles, including the open-and-obvious doctrine and deliberate encounter exception. It does not involve Massachusetts law, nor does it articulate any standard specific to ‘Massachusetts negligence law.’ While it discusses duties to maintain premises, warn, and take protective measures, it does so solely under Illinois law, so it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition as framed (a violation of Massachusetts negligence law).
Monteiro v. Stop & Shop, 871 N.E.2d 859.relevant_excerpt: “Against defendant Avalon, plaintiffs were proceeding on a theory of premises liability. The principles of premises liability were clearly set out by the Illinois Supreme Court in LaFever v. Kemlite Co., 185 Ill. 2d 380 (1998). A possessor of premises has a duty to guard against harm to an invitee. LaFever, 185 Ill. 2d at 391. There is an exception to this duty for ‘open and obvious hazards.’ … The deliberate encounter exception was the exception at issue in the case at bar.”

Bowers v. Lumare, Inc., 367 Mass. 688 (1.proposition: 12. Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain its premises in a safe condition, failing to warn of the dangerous condition, and failing to take prompt corrective action in violation of Massachusetts negligence law.
Bowers v. Lumare, Inc., 367 Mass. 688 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns custody and adoption proceedings and statutory requirements for Department of Public Welfare reports; it does not address premises liability, duty to maintain safe conditions, warn of dangers, or take corrective action. There is no discussion of negligence standards applicable to property owners under Massachusetts law. Accordingly, it does not support the negligence proposition cited.
Bowers v. Lumare, Inc., 367 Mass. 688 (1.relevant_excerpt: Under our statutes, the basic standard for adoption cases is what will serve “the best interests of the child.” G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c), as appearing in St. 1972, c. 800 § 2. Adoption of a Minor, 362 Mass. 842, 846 (1973). Such a standard presents the department and the trial judge with a classic example of a discretionary decision.
